text: Empeopled needs more people and more diverse content. We've lost users over time and a few political posters have taken over the front page. They're not breaking any rules so we can't do much about it at the moment.
I am going to say what I said on Discord a few days ago: Using Empeopled doesn't feel rewarding anymore.

Most of the people active on Empeopled are active in news and politics. The other categories are often neglected. Websites like Reddit excel in a wide variety of niches, because of their large userbase. You can have an active community of hundreds of people sharing images of wolves eating watermelons. That isn't a joke, either, it exists.

I just bought a house. A true log cabin built in 1939. I closed on March 27th and all things being a new homeowner have totally consumed my life. Seriously. I post about music here and there, or make a political comment once in a while, but that's been the extent of my online world. I haven't been online very much in the past 3 months, and I kinda like it! I'm still here, just not very much unfortunately. I'm on the Discord too and haven't been there either, at work right now, my laptop at home is collecting dust sitting on a stool.

The funny thing is, ever since @Citrogenen made a joke about "What will FairEnough complain about today" I have had trouble posting. (No blame to you Citro and I realize it was a joke!!) I don't often find other links online to share that aren't political, and at this point I don't post those because it's such a cesspool of rage on here. So I'm reduced to making posts about my life, which ends up being "OMG my cat found a mouse I'm freaking out" and I worry that you all have this image of me as a whiny Midwestern bitch that has nothing good to say about anything...so I lurk and make the..read more

1) they have a cartel so they can act collectively to mitigate/punish price fluctuations
2) they have more diversified economies.

A lot of topics were created during the Reddit Exodus. The problem is that a lot of those people have moved on. We've seen a gradual decline in activity/members over the last few months. We just don't have the numbers to sustain the topics. That's my take on the situation, anyway.

Earlier in Empeopleds life the threshold of votes needed to create a new topic was lower, and when there's an influx of new people, everyone races to propose new topics they're interested in. A lot of those people didn't stay around, however.

We're a smaller website, and working on continuously growing our content and userbase. It's a tricky balance but right now there are more topics than there are people to generate content and discussion for them.

Empeopled is growing slowly but surely. Unfortunately there aren't a lot of users contributing new content at the moment, especially in some of the smaller topics (even in the bigger ones too!). We definitely appreciate new people posting stuff if you should so choose.

Moderator, speaking officially: Moved to Empeopled Meta since it addresses the site. You're not at fault for this, but keep in mind that commentary related to the site would most likely go in Empeopled Meta.
Btw- this is why we had 10 topics pre-Reddit exodus. We can always vote to eliminate through the Change Committee if we want to simplify

So this is a complicated and tricky situation. I think in websites that grow, they eventually have certain people who manage the communication between admins and mods, or admins and community. These people generally are in touch with what is going on in the website, what issues they face, and ideas of how these issues can be solved. We could try to implement this - like a couple of Admin/Community Liason positions.
We could also try and form a separate committee altogether - a committee that reviews policies and the inner-workings of the site.
Or, another solution would be to just bring on..read more

The first concrete step would be to form a committee (for lack of better phrase) to come up with a set of by-laws similar to that of a 501c3. They would outline the basics of the governing body, separation of power, etc. The result would be most likely a board of directors with a chairperson/co-chair/triumvirate. I think the democratic nature of this site lends itself to this model well. This way the moderation of the site can be bifurcated from the administration.
So - what if we re-vote on the number of mod positions, community leader positions, and policy/liason positions?
